awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Mobile Behavioral and Medical Applications for Patient and Provider Interfacing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project focuses on content and data analytics design to attract patients with chronic diseases to navigate web and mobile based educational and self-care tools. It will also provide clinicians with surveillance for their practice and easy outreach in times of urgent need for vaccinations and health information, as well as to reduce care gaps in annual wellness visits and needed follow-up care.  Patient and provider usability will generate big data analytics to improve care and manage resources specific to the needs of the community. With millions of patient and health providers as users, the big data derived from these users will provide information to reduce healthcare costs for patients, providers, payers, the government and society.  

The proposed project is to incorporate and improve patient-centered care using web and mobile based custom software tools to support patients managing their health. Our research will allow for practitioners to focus on improving patient-physician engagement by measuring skills and behaviors of the patient when diagnosing and treating them. We will develop engaging content and software tools using secure and private web and mobile based health applications to promote smoking cessation, nutrition education, substance abuse reduction and cardiovascular care, providing data analytics from patients managing their disease on the platform to the care team's electronic health records or on the dashboards we provide.  This research, if successful will impact how big data analytics and outcomes measurement is communicated through consumerism and in the healthcare industry. The technology will incorporate customized IP dashboard for providers and patients; business decision modeling systems to make smarter decisions within the care continuum; custom analytics solutions that will offer relevant insights and reporting; advanced visualization of big data analytics that will provide very clear and concise representation of insights in an easy to interpret form, preventing the end-user from being bogged down with complex data; and predictive analytics to support clinical and patient decision making providing futuristic insights.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Accomplishments:

MediaHealth Technologies has developed key layers of a three-tier, multi-modal web-based platform in Advaita™ for healthcare practitioners to dispense to their patients in support of patient self-management of chronic disease(s). The Advaita™ platform system is designed to easily integrate with electronic health records and patient portals, and is highly flexible and dynamic which allows for new features to be introduced at a low-cost and a quick design turnaround.  The architecture and infrastructure were implemented into existing and proven cloud based frameworks which will allows for the system to be deployed rapidly. The development strategy has shaped the Advaita™ system into a minimal maintenance and extendable HIPAA compliant and secure tool for the healthcare industry. The robust data analytics table will offer the ability to provide improved clinical decision support with real-time data monitoring and tracking of patient compliance and consistency within program participation for chronic disease management.  A big achievement in this Phase I discovery is commercializing the nutrition education modulesv to providers for patient use.

Major Activities:

During the Phase I development of the minimum viable product (MVP)-- creating nutrition education modules, MHT conducted five human subject research pilot programs with 70 participants who presented or were diagnosed with one or more of the following health conditions: cardiovascular disease, hypertension/high blood pressure, prediabetes, high cholesterol, weight management, and type 2 diabetes. Data was collected on a cross-section of cultures, age, educational level, economic status and gender/lifestyle preferences within these populations. 

The overwhelming majority of respondents found the minimum viable product (MVP) -- nutrition education modules easy to navigate, informative and overall pleasant to use. The participants were particularly fond of the written content, videos and other visuals. They also found the modules particularly useful in deepening their knowledge on to how to maintain a balanced and healthy diet.

Impacts

The Advaita™ system will support reducing complications of type II diabetes and other preventable chronic diseases by improving patient self-management and care team engagement outside the clinic setting, using care plans and tools on dashboards  to push data and narratives of patients; allowing for patients to live a longer, healthier and happier quality of life. The platform will deliver to providers a global and holistic view of patient activity outside the clinic setting. The communication layers will also improve providers’ cultural competency skills. The solutions will prove a cause and effect—high uptake in provider adoption and patient use. The platform is uniquely designed to support the healthcare delivery system’s pivot toward reducing cost, increasing and improving on patient/provider engagement and strengthening the patient/provider relationship, overall improving patient satisfaction and treatment adherence.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC, 2016) 2014 Diabetes Report notes that more than 29 million people in the United States have diabetes, and another 86 million adults – more than one in three U.S. adults – have prediabetes, with 15-30% of people potentially will be diagnosed with type II diabetes. The CDC also notes that chronic diseases and conditions in the U.S., such as type II diabetes, are the most common, costly, and preventable of all health problems. Some of these factors are due to lack of exercise or physical activity, poor nutrition, tobacco use, and drinking too much alcohol which cause much of the illness, suffering, and early death.

The National Center for Health Statistics cited in 2013, that there were 130.4 million emergency department visits, but only 1.5 million people resulted in critical care units, 9.3% resulted in hospital admissions, and 29.8% of patient visits were treated in fewer than 15 minutes. The platform biometrics will be able to demonstrate a reduction in A1C at 6 and 18 months, show fewer acute symptoms, show increased exercise regimentation, demonstrate improved patient self-efficacy and improve patient/provider communication. CDC asserts that low-income populations, underserved and underrepresented groups are primarily at a higher risk for poor health outcomes and early death rates due to chronic diseases such as type II diabetes.

According to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Health Resources and Services Administration, ND), nearly 20 percent of Americans live in areas with an insufficient number of primary care doctors. Under federal guidelines, there should be no more than 3,500 people for each primary care provider, but according to the Association of American Medical Colleges (AAMC), unless something changes rapidly, there will be a shortage of 45,000 primary care doctors in the United States, as well as a shortfall of 46,000 specialists by 2020. The Advaita™ solution will support existing providers by reducing excessive use of office visits and emergency room visits while teaching patients improvements in self-care and chronic disease management. The system will also allow for providers to be available to care for patients who are unable to manage their health using our technology platform.

 


Last Modified: 12/18/2017
Modified by: Constance L Jackson
